user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_quote:
```c
size_t
MHD_str_quote (const char *unquoted,
               size_t unquoted_len,
               char *result,
               size_t buf_size)
{
  size_t r;
  size_t w;

  r = 0;
  w = 0;

#ifndef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  if (unquoted_len * 2 <= buf_size)
  {
    /* Fast loop: the output will fit the buffer with any input string content */
    while (unquoted_len > r)
    {
      const char chr = unquoted[r++];
      if (('\\' == chr) || ('\"' == chr))
        result[w++] = '\\'; /* Escape current char */
      result[w++] = chr;
    }
  }
  else
  {
    if (unquoted_len > buf_size)
      return 0; /* Quick fail: the output buffer is too small */
#else  /* MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
  if (1)
  {
#endif /* MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */

    while (unquoted_len > r)
    {
      if (buf_size <= w)
        return 0; /* The output buffer is too small */
      else
      {
        const char chr = unquoted[r++];
        if (('\\' == chr) || ('\"' == chr))
        {
          result[w++] = '\\'; /* Escape current char */
          if (buf_size <= w)
            return 0; /* The output buffer is too small */
        }
        result[w++] = chr;
      }
    }
  }

  mhd_assert (w >= r);
  mhd_assert (w <= r * 2);
  return w;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_str_quote:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined all uses of the function parameters (unquoted, unquoted_len, result, buf_size). There are no assignments to any parameter variables and no pointer reassignments. The code writes through result (result[w++] = ...), which modifies the object pointed to by the pointer parameter — this is allowed by the rule. The pointer variables themselves are never changed (no unquoted = ..., no result = ..., no unquoted++/result++), and scalar parameters unquoted_len and buf_size are only read (compared, multiplied) and not written. Loop indices r and w are local variables used for indexing and incremented; they are not function parameters. Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 and no fragments requiring further investigation for this rule.
